page.content: HISTORIC HOUSES Of the many interesting old houses in this area only Great Chalfield is open to the public. Domesday records that in Edward the Confessors time Caldefelle was held by Wallef. Later the manor came to William de Perci whose heirs held it for 6 generations, the last being Harry Percy who died on pilgrimage at Cologne in 1356. Chalfield was rebuilt and extended by Thomas Tropnell in the late 15th.c. The centre of the house is the great hall which has an oak screen with a gallery,two oriels at the east end, it is believed that the hall is the only one in England that has three stone looking masks from which a good view is obtained of activities below. There are many other features to the house including a solar, a groined room, a half timbered wing and a 90ft leat.
